{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3170504,"name":"joemost","username":"joemost","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joemost/{size}/11114_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:15:36.666Z","cooked":"

Our Robot has some cases where it becomes relatively tippy. IF we move our arm to the high front side of the robot driving at a high speed, and stop too quickly it is an automatic tip.

I’ve been thinking about how we help protect our drive from this issue and a ramp rate that gets enforced on our swerve system when we are cg compromised comes to mine. It becomes a little more complicated with swerve because we have to track that phase specifically but still.

Does anyone have any experience with this? Has it helped? Figured I’d ask around before we spend too much time messing with this.

I’m hesitant to do it because I don’t want the feel of the drive to change based on that, but it might also allow us to speed up that motion as the operator can do it in confidence knowing he won’t flip the whole thing!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:15:36.666Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":372,"readers_count":371,"score":134.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431313,"topic_slug":"have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips","display_username":"joemost","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips/431313/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3170507,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:17:50.843Z","cooked":"

Two words to protect against flips:

Battering Ram.

(in this case intake, but it has similar capabilities)

838A91051920×2688 483 KB

To answer your question though. Yes, had to do this last year with the tall 2767 machine.

Something something trapezoids

You’re probably looking at implementing a trapezoidal velocity profile for your drivetrain. These are an industry staple for motion control with finite power (or in this case, stability), and essentially boil down to limiting your acceleration as you calculate your desired wheel velocity.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:22:37.096Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":331,"readers_count":330,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431313,"topic_slug":"have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips","display_username":"Andrew H.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31984,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast"},"post_url":"/t/have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips/431313/3","custom_user_title":"Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3170516,"name":"joemost","username":"joemost","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joemost/{size}/11114_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:21:11.626Z","cooked":"

haha we had talked about basically making a rollbar… but in order to use it you’d actually have to begin to flip. I’ll go look at how 2767 looked!

If I limit how fastly the driver can slow himself when his velocity is above a certain velocity and the arm is in the cg exposed position, I’m hoping it would prevent that. My guess is it wouldn’t take much of a ramp, just enough to not stop instantly.

joemost:

I’ll go look at how 2767 looked

St Joe and Lakeview didn’t have as agressive limiting in the code, States and worlds had some ramping implemented IIRC (although driver practice helped too in 2022) still managed to dump the bot over at words though and toss a hundred ball bearings all over the side of the field from the turret.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:23:58.381Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":83.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":431313,"topic_slug":"have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips/431313/5","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3170522,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:23:47.072Z","cooked":"

We always tune slew rate limiters based on traction, driver feel, and tippyness. Last year we had a really high CG but slew rate limiters and driver practice made it where we never once flipped over even under heavy defense on multiple occasions and the wire protector on the field.

Making use of a variable slew rate based on CG would be more complicated as you would need to create a new one and seed its value when your “state” changes.

It definitely will require the drivers to get used to the inherent latency from the slewrate limiter but i would start there.

sounds good! yeah, thanks for the reply… just something to try. Driver Practice is obivously super important too

Our robot drives really nicely elsewhere regardless… its that one state (which were going to optimize how much we truly have to go to it)

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:26:57.204Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":259,"readers_count":258,"score":51.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":431313,"topic_slug":"have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips","display_username":"joemost","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":43759,"username":"Emerson1706","name":"Emerson OHara","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips/431313/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3170607,"name":"rafi","username":"rafi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rafi/{size}/9207_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T19:38:56.186Z","cooked":"

We always have an acceleration limit regardless of CG for various reasons like controllability and to mitigate voltage sag, and you could also adjust the acceleration limit based on certain conditions. I’d recommend implementing an acceleration limit and lowering it until your robot can no longer tip itself when the arm is raised, then add some logic to raise and lower the acceleration limit according to the arm state.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T19:38:56.186Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":73.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431313,"topic_slug":"have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips","display_username":"rafi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28673,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"449 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/have-you-ever-ramped-acceleration-to-protect-against-flips/431313/9","custom_user_title":"449 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3170615,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T19:45:03.349Z","cooked":"

OMG yes you should add some limits! And set your current limits to actual, sensible, non-wheel spinning numbers.

Your drivers will not notice well chosen limits, OTHER than not tipping the robot over. Both current and acceleration. If you -really- squash it down they WILL complain, so you DO need to do a bit of testing. Going from current limits above the wheel spinning threshold to just below will actually improve the robot handling

If you have your motors in brake mode this may get more complicated, as the zero stick input would be translated to: “stop darn quickly”.

Yes.

Our 2023 git repo has pretty sophisticated anti-tipping acceleration limiting code.

GitHub

Team 95 - The Grasshoppers

Team 95 - The Grasshoppers has 19 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

For a simple approach to ramping, you could try adding a SlewRateLimiter.
